stand.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to support yourself on your feet or be in an upright position
stand.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: It looks like we’ll have to stand – there are no seats left.
Stand still (=do not move) and listen to me.
Don’t just stand there (=stand and not do anything) – help me!
If he stood on tiptoe, he could reach the shelf.
stand on tiptoe/stand on your toes
We stood watching the rain fall.
stand.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to rise to an upright position
stand.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Smiling, she stood and closed the blinds.
stand.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Stand clear of the doors, please.
She stood back to let him in.
stand.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to accidentally step on or in something
stand.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to be upright in a particular position, or to put something or someone somewhere in an upright position
stand.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: A lamp stood on the table.
Near the railway station stood a hotel.
Some remains of the original house still stand.
Can you stand that pole in the corner for now?
I closed the lid and stood the case against the wall.
Stand Molly up on a chair so she can see.
stand.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to be or stay in a particular state or condition
stand.translation[0].definitions[5].note: stand in awe of somebody (=admire them, be afraid of them, or both)
stand.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: The kitchen door stood open so she went in.
I will know within the next month or two how I stand  (=what my situation is).
countries that have stood together (=stayed united) in times of crisis
scores of derelict houses standing empty
I’m not too thrilled with the way things stand (=the state that the situation is in) at the moment.
The evidence, as it stands (=as it is now), cannot be conclusive.
Where do things stand in terms of the budget?
He urged the whole community to stand united and to reject terrorism.
We should stand ready to do what is necessary to guarantee the peace.
stand.translation[0].definitions[6].type: transitive usually in questions and negatives
stand.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to be able to accept or deal well with a difficult situation
stand.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: She’s a strong woman who stands no nonsense from anyone.
I couldn’t stand the thought of leaving Danielle.
I’ve had about as much as I can stand of your arguing!
I don’t know if I can stand the waiting any longer.
How can you stand Marty coming home late all the time?
stand.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to be good or strong enough to last a long time or to experience a particular situation without being harmed, damaged etc
stand.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Linen can stand very high temperatures.
His poetry will stand the test of time (=stay popular).
stand.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to stay in a particular place without moving
stand.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: The car’s been standing in the garage for weeks.
The mixture was left to stand at room temperature for 15 minutes.
The train was already standing at the platform.
stand.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: The trophy stands five feet high.
stand.translation[0].definitions[10].def: to be at a particular level or amount
stand.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: Illiteracy rates are still thought to stand above 50 percent.
His former workforce of 1,300 now stands at 220.
stand.translation[0].definitions[11].def: to have a particular rank or position when compared with similar things or people
stand.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: The president stands high in the public opinion polls.
How do their sales stand in relation to those of similar firms?
His book could stand alongside the best.
stand.translation[0].definitions[12].def: to try to become elected to a council, parliament etc
stand.translation[0].definitions[12].exa: She announced her intention to stand for parliament.
stand.translation[0].definitions[13].def: if a decision, offer etc stands, it continues to exist, be correct, or be valid
stand.translation[0].definitions[13].exa: Despite protests, the official decision stood.
My offer of help still stands.
stand.translation[0].definitions[14].def: a liquid that stands does not flow or is not made to move
stand.translation[0].note_box[0].section: stand
to be on your feet in an upright position
There were no seats, so we had to stand.
When we entered, Stephen was standing by his desk.
be on your feet
to be standing, especially for a long time
If you have young kids, you’re on your feet all day.
I’d been on my feet since 7 o'clock and I needed to sit down.
The crowd were all on their feet clapping and calling for more.
get up
to stand after you have been sitting or lying down
He got up and turned off the TV.
Mum fell in her flat and was unable to get up.
stand up
to stand after you have been sitting, or to be in a standing position
I stood up when she came in and shook her hand.
It’s generally better to do this exercise standing up.
get to your feet
to stand up, especially slowly or when it is difficult for you
My attorney got slowly to his feet, breathing heavily.
to stand after you have been sitting, especially at a formal event
As the bride entered the cathedral, the congregation rose.
Audience members rose to their feet, cheering and clapping.
stand.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a piece of furniture or equipment used to hold or support something
stand.translation[1].definitions[0].note: coat stand/hat stand (=for hanging coats or hats on)
stand.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a table or small structure used for selling or showing things
stand.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The shop was crowded with display stands and boxes.
One week, three magazines hit the stands (=became available to buy) with Peace Corps stories.
stand.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a position or opinion that you state firmly and publicly
stand.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: She was accused of not taking a stand on feminism or civil rights.
the Republicans’ conservative stand on social and environmental issues
stand.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a strong effort to defend yourself or to oppose something
stand.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: We have to take a stand against racism.
stand.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: the period of time in which two batsmen are playing together in a game of cricket, or the points that they get during this time
stand.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: a place where taxis or buses stop and wait for passengers
stand.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: There’s a taxi stand on Glen Road.
stand.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: a group of trees of one type growing close together
stand.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to be at a particular level or amount
stand.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Your bank balance currently stands at £720.92.
stand.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to be in, stay in, or get into a particular state
stand.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The law, as it stood, favoured the developers.
I don’t see a serious challenge to London as a financial centre as things stand currently.
The committee stands divided (=disagrees completely) on this issue.
There are currently 65 industrial premises standing empty.
stand.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to continue to exist, be correct, or be VALID
stand.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The court of appeal has ruled that the conviction should stand.
stand.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: to refuse to change a decision, plan etc
stand.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: Harry’s standing pat on his decision to fire Janice.
stand.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: someone’s opinion about something, or the official rule about something
stand.translation[2].definitions[4].exam: The voters want to know where the President stands on taxes.
stand.translation[2].definitions[5].defi: to be brought to a court of law to have your case examined and judged
stand.translation[2].definitions[5].exam: The two men stood trial for allegedly attempting to receive stolen property.
stand.translation[2].definitions[6].defi: to pay money as a promise that someone will return to court to be judged
stand.translation[2].definitions[7].defi: to be the person in a court of law who is being judged for a crime
stand.translation[2].definitions[7].exam: He now stands accused by the city council of serious mismanagement of the museum’s financial affairs.
stand.translation[2].definitions[8].defi: to be likely to do or have something
stand.translation[2].definitions[8].exam: We stand to make a lot of money from the merger.
stand.translation[2].definitions[9].defi: to try to become elected to a parliament, board of directors etc
stand.translation[2].definitions[9].exam: He will not be standing for election as vice president this year.
Who’s standing for the Democrats in the 44th district?
stand.translation[2].definitions[10].def: to depend on something for success
stand.translation[2].definitions[10].exa: A product will stand or fall by its quality.
stand.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a small structure for selling or showing things
stand.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Come by our stand at the exhibition and see the new products.
stand.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: a position or opinion that you state firmly and publicly
stand.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: He did not take a stand on the proposed regulations.
